title: Mum says four daughters with Down’s syndrome were ‘easy peasy’
text:
Lorraine Cridge with her four girls (Picture: Chris Frear Butterfield for Metro.co.uk)

When Lorraine Cridge decided to start a family more than 30 years ago, not many parents were adopting children with disabilities.

The retired teacher said it was ‘unusual’ for parents to take on ‘so-called hard to place children’ with special needs.

But for Lorraine, it was something she always wanted to do.

She told Metro.co.uk: ‘Right from being a child I had an empathy for people with disabilities. I always felt they didn’t get a fair crack in society.

‘It sounds a bit weird to say it was like a calling. I don’t mean that in any religious way but it was.

‘It was something I knew I could do and wanted to do. I knew there were plenty of adopters around waiting for the “typical healthy white babies”.

‘I said let’s leave them for people who want that and let’s make a family from children who would otherwise not have a family of their own.’

Advertisement

Advertisement

Lorraine, along with husband Derek, still wanted a ‘normal family life’, filled with birthday parties, picnics in the park and seaside holidays, and the more they looked into children with Down’s syndrome, the more they believed it was ‘best thing for them’.

Lorraine Cridge says her girls were ‘easy-peasy’ growing up (Picture: Chris Frear Butterfield for Metro.co.uk)

Caption: Lorraine Cridge in Bottesford adopts (Picture: Chris Frear Butterfield for Metro.co.uk)

Lorraine said she always wanted to adopt children with disabilities (Picture: Chris Frear Butterfield for Metro.co.uk)

They became parents for the first time in 1986 when they welcomed Layla into their home in Scunthorpe, North Lincolnshire.

Within a couple of years, the parents applied to adopt another child, but this time, they were offered twins.

Lorraine said their family were ‘very concerned’ from the start and believed having three children with disabilities could be too much to handle.

She said: ‘They still had the old fashioned notion that people with learning disabilities were a burden.

‘They were very worried. When it came to the second adoption and we were asked to take twins, a lot of the family were saying three is an awful lot to take on.

‘They were expecting it to break down but it never did.’

Lorraine’s eldest and youngest, Layla and Lucy (Picture: Chris Frear Butterfield for Metro.co.uk)

All four girls live together in the family home, while their parents have moved out (Picture: Chris Frear Butterfield for Metro.co.uk)

Twin girls, Carlyn and Rose, were followed by Lucy, the couple’s fourth and final child.

Advertisement

Advertisement

Lorraine said they were always anticipating something to be difficult at each stage of their children’s lives, but it never happened.

She said: ‘It was easy peasy. Far less trouble than normal girls. I always knew where they were at night.

‘When they were all six to ten and I thought they’re all going to hit puberty and it will be terrible, but it wasn’t at all.

‘Maybe I was really lucky and managed to get four really good ‘uns but they were just not difficult.’

She added: ‘They’re not little angels but they are well-mannered and polite with people.

Lorraine Cridge in Bottesford adopts (Picture: Chris Frear Butterfield for Metro.co.uk)

Lorraine says Layla has taken on the maternal role in the house (Picture: Chris Frear Butterfield for Metro.co.uk)

‘They with mix well with both mainstream and special needs, but they don’t see any different between themselves and anybody else.

‘They were brought up to believe no one is better than anybody else.’

Fast forward three decades and all four girls are grown up and living together in the family home, while mum and dad have moved out.

Lorraine said Layla, now aged 32, Carlyn and Rose, 30, and Lucy, 28, are all very different.

She added: ‘Layla is very kind and considerate and has taken on the more maternal role, doing most of the housework.

‘She tries to get them to do it but she ends up going into their rooms and tidying up after them.’

Twins Carlyn and Rose are inseparable as you might expect (Picture: Chris Frear Butterfield for Metro.co.uk)

Lucy is always making people laugh (Picture: Chris Frear Butterfield for Metro.co.uk)

‘The twins are much quieter on the outside, until they get to know people. They are very much in the twin mould. They are very close and stick together a lot.

Advertisement

‘Where one goes, the other will always go with them.

‘Lucy is like Tigger on speed. She’s a bit hyperactive, bouncing off the walls and is just so funny.

‘She has everybody in stitches the whole time, she’s a real comedian.’

Lorraine said there are ‘no boundaries’ on children with learning difficulties these days.

She added: ‘You might still have to fight a little bit for inclusion.

‘But it’s there for the taking. You might have to be more determined because you do have to fight for their rights.

‘Some people will still say “you can’t go there” so you have to be prepared to say “tell me why?”

‘I would encourage anybody to adopt children with disabilities.

‘They’ve enriched our lives immensely. They’ve given us a lot more than we’ve given them.’
